21966755.review:
You're probably well-familiar with the Hyperdimension franchise by now. Alongside Compile Heart's most popular RPG series, Idea Factory has commissioned the assistance of various developers, in order to produce spin-offs. It seems like every year, two or more Neptunia games are being released. Are we heading towards complete global saturation? It's too soon to tell. For now, let's look at the first spin-off to hit Steam: [i]Hyperdimension Neptunia U: Action Unleashed[/i]. In the interest of sanity, I'm shortening the title to [i]NepU[/i] for the remainder of the review.

[i]NepU[/i] is by Tamsoft, the same developer responsible for the [i]Onechanbara[/i] and [i]Senran Kagura[/i] franchises. Those games are known for their fast-paced hack & slash action... among other things, but let's not get side-tracked just yet. Anyway, the plot of this game follows Famitsu and Dengikiko, two rival gaming-magazine writers looking for the next big story. Since Gamindustri revolves around the actions of the CPUs as well as the CPU Candidates, you can guess where this is going. Neptunia and company team up to complete quests and slash hundreds upon thousands of monsters.

Fans of [i]Musou[/i]-styled games will feel right at home upon starting this one. Each quest consists of a small arena where monsters constantly spawn. By pressing the X and Y buttons, Nep & the gang perform a dizzying array of moves to decimate these hordes. There are also special attacks as well as HDD transformations for that touch of variety. For most quests, it's best to form a tag-team. Each of the 10 playable characters can team up, so if nothing else, you have Nepgear for backup in case Neptune takes a dirtnap. Your mission is usually some variation of "kill everything", but sometimes there can be hidden objectives or mid-boss battles. The heroines also level-up and earn monster-medals, which can boost stats and unlock equipment. 

Since this is a Neptunia game and it is by Tamsoft, a little somethin' somethin' is provided for the fans. You know what I'm talking about right? Fan-service. Unlike most videogames, clothes are not immune to damage. Depending on the severity of the attack, the ladies can get stripped to their skivvies. This affects HDD forms as well. The loss of clothes can result in more damage, for you as well as the enemy. Visually, getting stripped affects some characters more than others. For Vert's HDD form, her attire changes from "leaves little to the imagination" to "Who needs imagination?" In case all of this makes you uncomfortable, damage-immune clothing can be easily acquired. 

Overall I think that the combat is fun, but also not very deep. This can be attributed to the lack of difficulty. While the monsters can hit pretty hard, in most circumstances, they'll never get the chance to attack. The ladies of Gamindustri are usually too powerful to be threatened by these pitiful creatures. Their moves have a lot of range, and monsters are easily stunned. When the ladies are transformed, whatever semblance of a sliver of threat that the monsters had slips away. If a quest is giving you trouble, it's probably because you're attempting something that is too high a level. Unfortunately, the level of difficulty never really achieves the right balance. As with the Neptunia RPGs, the challenge of the post-game is in dealing with monsters that have mountains of HP, and are capable of killing level 99 heroines in a couple hits. It might be best to approach this portion of the game with a "don't get hit" mindset. There are a couple accessories that trade survivalability for increased damage output. Dodging projectiles and other attacks is pretty satisfying, but for the most part, you'll be too busy crushing everything to notice.

Alongside the lack of challenge is the absence of conflict. Unlike the Console Industry, everyone in Gamindustri gets along like chocolate and pretzels. Didn't the first Neptunia RPG start off with the CPUs fighting to the death? I know they're all friends now, but shouldn't some attempts have been made to introduce a rivalry in NepU that goes beyond mild teasing? In the [i]Onechanbara[/i] and [i]Senran Kagura[/i] games, you might cut through a lot of mindless zombies and kunoichi, but you also have to contend with rivals. These opponents have abilities that are on par with your own. Aside from an optional and underutilized bonus mode, there aren't any instances where the CPUs and Candidates fight each other. 

This to me is the perfect example of a missed opportunity. I've played and enjoyed the three Re;Birth RPGs, and while they're all pretty easy, their storylines feel "earned". The characters in these games might have wacky personalities and form-fitting attire, but they also run into problems, argue, and even fight each other. Eventually they rise up to the challenge and defeat the villains that have troubled them throughout their adventure. [i]NepU[/i] doesn't have any real adversaries, and the big bad boss is only fought twice, in two very lop-sided battles. There isn't even a lame excuse for the heroines to fight each other. Even if it was something petty like Noire accusing Blanc for stealing her quests, it would make for a more interesting story. Naturally, this would translate into a more dynamic game, especially if you had to adopt a second style of fighting, in order to deal with rivals. Perhaps these opponents could have monsters under their control, and... well you get the idea. 

The PC port is fantastic. Support for a plethora of resolutions and 60 fps? This game's got them. If you're looking for crashes or major bugs, you'll have to look elsewhere. The load-times are also far better than in the Vita version. I suppose that's to be expected, but it's welcome all the same. While not specifically related to the port, I really appreciate that all of the skits are voiced in English. This wasn't the case for the Re;Birth games, and I found myself defaulting to the Japanese voices, because the silence was irritating.

In conclusion, [i]NepU[/i] succeeds if you're looking for something different from the Neptunia universe. There are some hilarious moments, and the process of gaining levels and slaughtering monsters is dumb fun. However, this game just isn't designed to remain compelling for a long period of time. Other hack & slash titles, including those by Tamsoft, offer far more depth and content. While this game is just a spin-off, I sincerely believe that more could have been done with it. Even die-hard followers of the Nep-Nep faith should take caution before plunging into this amusing but shallow diversion. 

[i]If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Original_Curators_Group#curation]Follow Original Curator Group[/url][/i]

40202301.review:
Buen juego de Hack'n'slash, con el que quitarse la adrenalina pulsando como loco los botones y repartiendo tortas a diestro y siniestro y, con un ligero toque erótico.
Cada personaje tiene su propio estilo y particularidades a la forma de enfrentarse a los enemigos, lo cual tiene su relevancia a la hora de llevar a cabo las misiones.
Sistema de recompensas en forma de medallas que se pueden intercambiar por más puntos de ataque, defensa o vida, de forma que cada vez evolucionamos más a los 12 personajes del juego, así como armas cada vez más potentes por personaje.

40156533.review:
1st of all, if you like waifus, this game is for you. Runs good, not a single crash,  framerate never went down. 
Gameplay can become repetetive for some audience, combat is easy, combos are extremely easy, there is nothing complex about this game. It is more like a "when you just wanna anti-stress" type of game (Except for two achievements if you like to get them). It has a lot of text with a non-rich lore thing, it's casual but... entertains at is very least. The presentation of this game is quite good with all the things that you can do. Customizable characters / various type of games (Yeah, once you finish the main game), voice acting is good ... This is most likely how a Visual Novels looks on steroids. 

2nd of all, So, I've been playing this game with keyboard...
... And what's the fuss? I mean, i've read a lot of comments that this game is almost unplayable without controller... I remaped almost the entire layout and I was able to finish all the game even fight against the IA in Gamindustri Gauntlet pro tier. 

Can be quite annoying at first but, like everything... took me like 10 mins to adapt. 

WASD + NumPad keys work perfeclty fine, camera movement with Q / E also works great (But.. but.. howbout up/down) , easy too, Z/X  and if I used it like 3 or 5 times was that much.

40091994.review: This is a very fun spinoff to the dynasty warrior games. At first I didn't think much of it but once I realized that it had Neptunia waifus and armor break, I was just blown away. The cast of characters include the classic Gen 1 Cpus and Gen 2 Sister Cpus alongside with Dengekiko and Famitsu. It still has all the classic things Nepunia games are known but with new elements like news interviews and medals (BTW THE LILY RANKING SYSTEM IS MEGA GAY). It also provides a fun and uplifting story (even if it takes like 5 hours to complete). The game has very little to offer when it comes to content which is a HUGE con considering how fun it is (which is why I reccomend getting the DLC, SO WORTH). I rate this game 10/10 would armor break again.

39964020.review:
Vou escrever essa análise com pesar no coração !

[b]Prós :[/b]
- Jogabilidade
- Trilho Sonora
- Como sempre às personagens de Neptunia são carismáticas
- Dublagem JP impecável como sempre
- O sistema de medalhas eu achei muito bom.

[b]Neutro :[/b]
- Jogabilidade , para alguns pode ser um porre.

[b]Senta que lá vem bomba ![/b]

[b]Contras :[/b]
- Arenas grandes pra caramba com pouquissímos mobs , ele é um hack 'n' slash com uma cara de Musou bem meh.
- Poucos equipamentos
- Pouca variedade de roupa / roupas na forma Deusa
- Não têm visualização prévia das roupas
- [b]O end-game é um PORRE ![/b]
- Os personagens long range [b]( Ram,Rom,Uni )[/b] têm 0 variação de combos , é só ficar spammando um botão ad eternum.
- O jogo fica lento do NADA 

Consideração FInal : Claramente é um jogo que foi dado [b]DOIS TAPAS[/b] e lançaram , poderia ter sido muito melhor , menos enjoativo e nem é pelo o gênero hack 'n' slash o jogo é chato mesmo! Só recomendo a compra pra quem é fã de [b]Nepnep[/b] e compre esse jogo em promoção , não pague preço full nem fu***** !

Nota : 6.0
